[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

During their travels through western Europe (1763-1768) and in\u00a0Italy\u00a0(1769-1773), the Mozarts collected souvenirs of the places they had visited, the monuments, holy places, natural wonders and people they had seen or met. In part these souvenirs served to remind them later of their journeys\u2014to evoke memories of where they had been and who they had met\u2014and in part they were intended to be shown to friends and acquaintances where they had been and to supplement their descriptions of those people and places with visual imagery and objects.

"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"caption": "

Caption - wrap right

", "image": 1, "alignment": "right"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Naples and Mount Vesuvius"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Only very occasionally does one see a little smoke. But we shall shortly be seeing it at close quarters.\u2019 They had a better view of an eruption on 5 June, when Mozart wrote to his sister, \u2018Smoke is pouring out of Vesuvius\u00a0today, odds fish and zounds,\u2019 and they visited the volcano on 18-19 June, when\u00a0Leopold Mozartwrote: \u2018On Monday and Tuesday etc. we`re going to take a closer look at Vesuvius, Pompea and Herculaneum - the towns that are currently being excavated - and admire the curiosities that have already been discovered and also take a look at Caserta\u00a0etc. and\u00a0Capo di Monte\u00a0etc.\u2019 Mozart and his father purchased or were given two souvenirs of their encounter with Vesuvius, some lava and a copper engraving that shows the volcano in the background. The lava they acquired does not survive; the engraving they purchased or were given survives in the library of the Salzburg Museum: Both in Italy, between 1769 and 1773, and during the family tour of western Europe, from 1763 to 1766, the Mozarts were avide collectors of engravings of cityscapes and landscapes. Some of the engravings they collected in London and Naples, together with the engraving of Vesuvius, also survive in the library of the Salzburg Museum [= link to screens showing engravings]. Engravings from Paris and Rome mentioned in the family letters are lost, as are other souvenirs acquired by the Mozarts that are mentioned in their correspondence [= link to screen outlining known but lost \u2013 so have reversed 1a and 1b/c from below. This seems to me more logical. Then link at bottom of 1 to 2, The Mozarts as Producers of Souvenirs]

"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"caption": "

Caption - wrap left

", "image": 1, "alignment": "left"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Only very occasionally does one see a little smoke. But we shall shortly be seeing it at close quarters.\u2019 They had a better view of an eruption on 5 June, when Mozart wrote to his sister, \u2018Smoke is pouring out of Vesuvius\u00a0today, odds fish and zounds,\u2019 and they visited the volcano on 18-19 June, when\u00a0Leopold Mozartwrote: \u2018On Monday and Tuesday etc. we`re going to take a closer look at Vesuvius, Pompea and Herculaneum - the towns that are currently being excavated - and admire the curiosities that have already been discovered and also take a look at Caserta\u00a0etc. and\u00a0Capo di Monte\u00a0etc.\u2019 Mozart and his father purchased or were given two souvenirs of their encounter with Vesuvius, some lava and a copper engraving that shows the volcano in the background. The lava they acquired does not survive; the engraving they purchased or were given survives in the library of the Salzburg Museum: Both in Italy, between 1769 and 1773, and during the family tour of western Europe, from 1763 to 1766, the Mozarts were avide collectors of engravings of cityscapes and landscapes. Some of the engravings they collected in London and Naples, together with the engraving of Vesuvius, also survive in the library of the Salzburg Museum [= link to screens showing engravings]. Engravings from Paris and Rome mentioned in the family letters are lost, as are other souvenirs acquired by the Mozarts that are mentioned in their correspondence [= link to screen outlining known but lost \u2013 so have reversed 1a and 1b/c from below. This seems to me more logical. Then link at bottom of 1 to 2, The Mozarts as Producers of Souvenirs]

The lava they acquired does not survive; the engraving they purchased or were given survives in the library of the Salzburg Museum: Both in Italy, between 1769 and 1773, and during the family tour of western Europe, from 1763 to 1766, the Mozarts were avide collectors of engravings of cityscapes and landscapes. Some of the engravings they collected in London and Naples, together with the engraving of Vesuvius, also survive in the library of the Salzburg Museum [= link to screens showing engravings]. But we shall shortly be seeing it at close quarters.\u2019 They had a better view of an eruption on 5 June, when Mozart wrote to his sister, \u2018Smoke is pouring out of Vesuvius\u00a0today, odds fish and zounds,\u2019 and they visited the volcano on 18-19 June, when\u00a0Leopold Mozartwrote: \u2018On Monday and Tuesday etc. we`re going to take a closer look at Vesuvius, Pompea and Herculaneum - the towns that are currently being excavated - and admire the curiosities that have already been discovered and also take a look at Caserta\u00a0etc. and\u00a0Capo di Monte\u00a0etc.\u2019 Mozart and his father purchased or were given two souvenirs of their encounter with Vesuvius, some lava and a copper engraving that shows the volcano in the background. Some of the engravings they collected in London and Naples, together with the engraving of Vesuvius, also survive in the library of the Salzburg Museum [= link to screens showing engravings]. [{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

During their travels through western Europe (1763-1768) and in\u00a0Italy\u00a0(1769-1773), the Mozarts collected souvenirs of the places they had visited, the monuments, holy places, natural wonders and people they had seen or met. In part these souvenirs served to remind them later of their journeys\u2014to evoke memories of where they had been and who they had met\u2014and in part they were intended to be shown to friends and acquaintances where they had been and to supplement their descriptions of those people and places with visual imagery and objects.
